title: Nerf Dart Shower Caddy Anchor (Parametric)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a simple parametric shower caddy anchor that uses a Nerf dart suction cup to keep the caddy stable. There are nine parameters that can be used to define the object, but if you're using standard Nerf suction darts and your shower caddy wire diameter is about 5.5mm, then the stl will probably work just fine for you. For me, this required about 285mm of filament -- about 5 cents.

1) Print one or more of the anchors, tweaking the "user-defined values" if necessary to customize it. 2) Pull the suction cup(s) off of a Nerf suction dart (e.g. http://amzn.com/B00284C4FK -- or you can get them at places like Walmart) and clean off any remaining glue 3) Attach dart head to shower caddy anchor as pictured, and install.

title: ANET A8 Filament Sensor Switch/Guide (out of filament, filament jam)

description.text:
UPDATED: I've modified this to now be able to sense filament spool jams. Everything else, code wise, works the same. The new versions are named 'filament_jam_sensor. There is a switch body and a sensor arm. You will need a small machine screw to hold the arm to the switch body.

I had a collection of springs around and found one about 18mm long by 10.5mm diameter that worked pretty well for this.

The sketchup file has another version in it where you can use rubber bands, if you can't find a spring.

I was tired of dealing with dribs and drabs of filament left on my spools so I thought I would put something together. I had seen a number of other projects with optical and mechanical switches, but none matched this batch of microswitches I had on hand, so off to skecthup to design something.

This is designed to be both a filament guide and a sensor. On my machine it's a perfect friction fit on the acrylic crossbar of the printer. The cover for the switchbox is also a friction fit. On my print, it fit's quite tight and does not require glue to stay on.

I'm using the octoprint plugin octoprint filament reloaded
https://github.com/kontakt/Octoprint-Filament-Reloaded

The switch is an SV-166-1c25. It seems pretty widely available, just google it and you'll find a supplier.

So, It's pretty basic. What this does is when your filament runs out, it will pause the print, let you put in a new spool, and then resume printing, assuming you are using octoprint.

I had a little trouble getting this to run due to 2 misunderstandings on my part.
1) This uses the 'board' number on the raspberry pi, not the 'bcm' number. The board number is the physical pin number. The bcm number is the GPIONN number.

2) I had been testing this initially on a pretty large model. I 'think' that this will only pause between levels on the print. So I wasn't being patient enough and kept going back and forth wondering why it wasn't working.

Once I stuck with the board number and used a smaller model for testing, I was able to verify that every thing was working the way it should. I also started watching the .octoprint/logs/octoprint.log file for the messages indicating it was working.

Pin Connections.
I already had a dual relay connected to the gpio pins on my Pi to be able to turn the printer on/off and turn some led lights I have mounted on/off.
The connections for the relay used pings 04,06, 12, and 16.

for the switch I ended up connecting it to pins 18(gpio24) and 20(gnd)

In the settings for the Filament Sensor Reloaded plugin, I have it set for :
Pin 18
Switch Type Normally Closed
Board Pin Mode - Board

For the Out Of Filament Gcode, I have it set to change the display on the printer to show 'Out of Filament'

I have it set to pause when out of filament. This is cool because it will run the pause and resume scripts from the Ocotprint Control panel.

I have the pause and resume settings setup to move the print head out of the way so I can change the filament, and then it will go back and resume printing where it left off. I did not create these commands, I just found them out on the internet. They seem to do what I want, so I haven't messed with them much.

All in all, This seems like a pretty slick setup and I want to commend the folks that put together octoprint and the filament sensor reloaded plugin, and the folks I stole the rest of this design and scripts from, for a job well done.

Pause Settings
; relative XYZE
G91
M83
; retract filament, move Z slightly upwards
G1 Z+5 E-5 F4500
; absolute XYZE
M82
G90
; move to a safe rest position, adjust as necessary
G1 X0 Y0

Resume Settings
; relative extruder
M83
; prime nozzle
G1 E-5 F4500
G1 E5 F4500
G1 E5 F4500
; absolute E
M82
; absolute XYZ
G90
; reset E
G92 E{{ pause_position.e }}
; move back to pause position XYZ
G1 X{{ pause_position.x }} Y{{ pause_position.y }} Z{{ pause_position.z }} F4500
; reset to feed rate before pause
G1 {{ pause_position.f }}

title: Golf counter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A 'Jenny Cash' golf counter

  • counts up to 11, making it a 2-digit counter
  • noticeable click sound
    It is very simple, both in design and in mechanics - it should last for long.

It's fully ABS printable, with a 0.4mm nozzle and 0.2mm layer height, including the spring. Support is required. Additionally needed parts:

  • 2 screws M2x4 flat-head/sunken head (can be self-cutting)
  • one short rubber band

Building: Start upside down, and put in the wheel first. The rubber band shall have an initial tension to always bring back the lever. Hook it on the left side, go over the bar on the left side of the lever, twist it, go over the lever, twist it again before going over the right bar and hook it on the right side. Put on the lid and lock it with the screws.

You could print the numbers with a different color, either with a dual-extruder setup or simply by switching the filament.
You could print the spring (and everything) in PETG. PLA can be used for everything but the spring.

Edit: Added a zip with all parts individually, with an update knob.

title: Handlebar mount for the Garmin GPSmap 60C series

description.text:
This is a bike handlebar mount for the Garmin GPSmap 60C series of handheld GPS devices.
It is designed for a handlebar with a diameter of 31.8mm.

Its has a clamp with hinge and one screw, so its can be easy open to mount.

Device is mounted into the holder in same way like in product Garmin 010-10454-00, but its sits in this mount more secure and stable (this is more important in MTB). During pressing the buttons, the device feels a lot more stiff, which significantly improves the handling of the device during ride.
Used for over 1000km along forest and mountain paths and works great.
The original product Garmin 010-10454-00 broke down very quickly after several rides, and the usability of the GPS on it was fatal.

title: Mini TV rétro
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
La miniaturisation est de rigueur en cette « rétro-période », je pense à la mini NES, la mini Atari, la mini Megadrive et la future miniSNES ! Il manquait donc un truc…quelque chose qui nous démangeait depuis un moment et qui finalement se révèle complémentaire ! Une mini TV, Rétroooo ! Évidement …

Vous pouvez jeter un œil à sa construction ici : http://game-makers.xyz/_ArcadeMaker/ArcadeMaker_Article007.html

Descriptif :
Mini TV avec un style bien rétro, équipée d’un système de jeux intégré (recalbox) capable de recevoir des sources vidéo extérieures de type analogique et numérique.

Fonctionalités :
Possibilité de jouer sur secteur ou sur batterie, un bon système audio, et plusieurs options vidéo (RCA, VGA, HDMI)

Mesures :
Longueur: 254 mm
Largeur: 198 mm
Hauteur: 152 mm
Poids: 3kg

Elements de la structure :

Sur le dessus :
Une antenne factice bien rétro

En façade :
deux portes à droite qui hébergent :

  • Potentiomètre du son
  • Entrée de la carte SD
  • Un port USB dédié à la clef 158 giga qui hébergera les jeux du Raspberry
  • Une prise casque jack 3.5
  • Deux ports USB pour brancher 2 manettes
  • Un petit LCD qui indique le niveau de la batterie en %
  • Une led infrarouge cachée qui permet l’utilisation d’une télécommande pour gérer l’écran.

De chaque cotés :
Deux Haut-parleurs puissants

Au dos :

  • Deux prises RCA (vidéo + son)
  • Une entré VGA
  • Un port RJ45
  • Une entrée HDMI
  • La télécommande filaire de l’écran
  • Deux boutons ( ON/OFF PI, USB )
  • Module 220V
  • Boutons permettant la sélection du mode batterie/secteur
  • Un port USB délivrant du 5V depuis la batterie afin d’alimenter la mini NES/SNES en mode autonome

En dessous :

  • Quatre pieds dont deux réglables en hauteur
  • Plusieurs aérations localisées

A l'intérieur :

  • En jaune le bloc central qui contient toute l’électronique,
  • En bleu les HP.

description.text:
I know there are A lot of these on Thingiverse but this is my take on it.
This is my third design of the key chain and after a several months of use it still looks good. It is bolted together with 4 3m x 13 bolts and nuts. and has spacers were bolts go though where there are no keys to stop flex. This one was designed to hold 4 keys but one could modify the height of the spacers for more or less keys.

comments.text: When you say it's designed to hold 4 keys, is that on each side, or total?
comments.author: AbuMaia

comments.text: With the design posted it's 4 keys total. If you change the height of the spacers you can make it hold as many keys as you like.
comments.author: AbuMaia

comments.text: Nice concept. I think the thickness can be 3mm instead of four as the part itself is pretty big. Also, a few more pictures of how to put this together would help a lot. I ended up using pliers to insert the nuts on this. I printed at .2 layer and .3 extruder and It was still pretty tight. The holes I also forced the screws in. Countersinking the screw side would be good too so it's all nice and flat on both sides. Nothing to snap if you want it this thick. Just thought I let you know. Okay, now that I got most of it together I can say that this was a lesson in frustration getting this put together. I like the idea but the design needs work.
comments.author: jaimenow

comments.text: It has been some time since I put this together myself but I do remember making the tolerances tight. I used pliers to but my nuts in too. I wanted them to stay in place should I need to take it apart to change keys.

description.text:
Slide in RAMPS mount with 1 x 80mm fan for my Hypercube build. The optional fan-bracket can be removed simply by unscrewing the M5 bolts.

The slide in mount should be easy and fast to print. The fan cover requires supports and more time...
On my printer I got the best results printing the fan cover on its side, with the "arch" down. The flange for the screw holes should also indicate the best direction to print it with minimal amount of supports.

The bracket for the fan will probably print fine on its side with supports in the fan opening. I tried printing it with the fan opening down, but Cura didn't add sufficient supports. Your slicer may do a better job with this.

title: Household iCamera-1000 or similar 1/4-20 POE webcam wall/ceiling

description.text:
Uses two 1/4-20 bolts and one 1/4-20 nut (fender washer optional). The Ball is designed with removable supports that hold the ball and a 1" 1/4-20 bolt. You must check in your slicer preview at which layer the bolt opening will close up and pause at or near that layer so that you can use the printer software to jog the nozzle out of the way so you can inset the bolt. Multiple copies can be printed at the same time, you just need to pause at the correct layer so the encased bolts can be inserted.
I have included a version of the bolt_ball that has the pause built in, but your setup may vary from mine. I'm using a USB connection to my PC and Reptier Host 2.0.0. The Repetier can accommodate the "@pause " command, but not if it's on an SD card, the printer will simply ignore the line to pause and just keep on printing.
Assembly should be fairly straight forward. Insert one bolt into the ball clamp and insert the ball with the bolt in it into the clamp.
Insert that assembly into the base clamp first and add a nut to the back and snug it down.
Trim the ball supports from the bolt using diagonal cutters/pliers/dremel cutter/hobby knife.
Mount your camera and your done.
The clamp is designed to not really need hand tools. In fact you only need the same tension if you used a 1/4-20 wingnut and your hand.

Notes:

You may want to pre-heat the bolts by just setting them on the print bed after the nozzle has gained clearance height. Also you may want to give the bolts a light spray of hairspray. The heat and hairspray will help with adhesion of the print filament to the bolt head, but not really necessary as the ball was designed to just bridge over the bolt head, but the warm bolts did bridge better than room temp ones.
Inland PLA 1.73mm measured and applied to the filament section of the printer settings on PC

title: Eagles & Colours 10mm Risk Napoleonic Insert for Kallax Storage and Markers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Combination of miniature storage/sorting insert for the Kallax/Expedit trays I designed along with basing, markers and grouping rings for "Eagles and Colours" (https://www.scribd.com/document/215268952/Eagles-Colours-Ver0-6) if you are collecting and using Risk 10mm Napoleonic miniatures for that wargame. I recommend the standard 1.75" depth trays located at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2202792 for use with the insert presented here. The plug files are sized for Tabloid but are meant to be lasercut on .045" cardstock (10"x16") to level out and underpin the basing provided for different Risk sets. If you own these Risk figures you'll figure them out.

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from 12" x 9" (Arch C) 24" x 18" sheet size, which fits across the bed of an Epilog Helix. All my patterns are designed to be laser cut at 300dpi. I have only provided the PDF as the SVG conversion will not accept the fonts used to produce the PDF. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. And if you download this, please LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

  • 1 x 0.7x4.5x14mm spring
  • 4 x 3.5x25mm screw
  • 1 x M5x30mm bolt
  • 1 x M5x4mm nut

Notes:

  • use thread lock glue on the nut
  • use black plastic (or paint) for the rotor
  • HC-020K sensor works at both 3.3V and 5V

Signal:

  • Gear circumference (C=πD): C=34.55 mm
  • Rotor pulses (see model): P=30 pulse per turn
  • Encoder signal rate (E=P/C): E=0.8681 pulse per mm

title: Tronxy P802E 608 Bearing Z Axis Reinforcing Brackets

description.text:
Brackets to reinforce the upper cross member and vertical frame intersection with added 608 bearing support for the leadscrews.

There are various discussions on the merits and potential pitfalls in the use of bearings at the top of the leadscrews. I can only speak from experience and found the installation of the brackets with 608 bearings made a marked improvement in print quality and also reduced resonant noise in the printer itself. According to various posts out there your mileage may vary. The leadscrew flopping around in an oversized plastic hole just wasn't doing it for me.

Installation is simple. Unscrew the two top bracket screws. Relocate the guide rod end stop onto the printed bracket. Insert bearing and replace bracket on frame re-installing the two screws. Bowden extruder mount is retained for those who use it.

Carcassone is a tile-laying game.  The 'game board' grows as the tiles are laid, in whatever direction the tiles fit.  In our games there has been a continuing problem in keeping the tiles straight, and it can become a major operation if the 'board' has to be shifted if it nears a table edge.  The Tile Grids each hold nine tiles in perfect alignment, and the grids snap together with small dovetail joints to grow the board in any direction as necessary.  There are small raised ridges between each tile, but this doesn't detract from the game.  A small game can be held by about ten grids, but a large one with many expansions could take 20 or more grids.  The photos show a game as it expands over time.

This is pretty much a printer calibration object, as it extends from front to back on a Replicator platform, giving lots of opportunity for lifting corners.  Your platform -must- be aligned.  Let the platform cool a bit before lifting or the grid will warp.  (If you do warp one, heat up the platform again and use something to press it flat.)  
Printed at 0.2mm layer height, 100% fill.
The fit of the dovetail joints has worked perfectly for me, but the fit might depend a bit on your filament width.  A bit of a trim with an x-acto knife might be necessary.
I've printed them in black and green ABS, and was thinking that the green would be less obtrusive, but my daughter has used both and prefers the black.

comments.text: These are great - the best part being that if a tabletop of tiles is expanding too much in one direction, it is EASY to slide the whole thing to accommodate. Great job and thanks!

description.text:
My wife has the Topeak QuickTrack rack system on her bike. She recently bought the Topeak basket that works with the system, however, the geometry of the bike seat and basket are such that she couldn't slide the basket far enough forward to engage the latch without hitting the back of the seat.

My solution? Re-engineer the latch to give some extra space. Here is my model. Perhaps it will be helpful to someone else in a similar situation.

I am working on a Version 2 that includes a little bump on the tongue so the basket can't slide forward while you are riding. Also, the holes are not quite big enough for the screws that come with the "Fixer 6" adapter from Topeak, so Version 2 will also have bigger holes. In the meantime, you can drill them out yourself with a 5/32" bit.

print_settings.Notes:: Print 2 sides (regular or stubby), one pin (for 6-32 screw or for M4, as you prefer) and one washer.  You will also need two 9mm wide mini-snap knife blades, two short pieces of 1.75 mm dia. filament and one short 6-32 or M4 screw.

description.text:
This pair of scissors uses mini-snap knife blades that are easily replaceable so you can always keep them sharp. The blades are held in place with a short length of 1.75mm dia. filament that snaps into a retaining channel. These are light duty scissors for sure - they work best on paper, thread, light cloth etc.. I've included two different side pieces - long and stubby. The stubby work better for cutting at the tip.

CAUTION: Be really careful when handling and using the snap knife blades - they are razor sharp!

Printer:

UDIO

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print 2 sides (regular or stubby), one pin (for 6-32 screw or for M4, as you prefer) and one washer. You will also need two 9mm wide mini-snap knife blades, two short pieces of 1.75 mm dia. filament and one short 6-32 or M4 screw.

Clean up any supports and any debris that might be in the blade channel. Also clean out the notch in the pivot hole on each side as any debris will limit the range of motion.

Place the blade in the channel. Oddly, you can either use the sharp edge up or the square edge up. on one or both sides. If you are making the stubby version, break off the blade to the proper length at one of the score marks. Place your short length of filament alongside the blade and snap it into place using a small screwdriver Trim off any excess filament.

Insert the pin in one side and then assemble the other side onto the rest of the pin. Secure both sides together with a 6-32 or M4 screw.

Experiment with flipping the blades sharp edge up or square edge up on one or both blades - you get slightly different cutting behavior with each combination.

description.text: This is a stand designed to let you play with the Switch positioned vertically, which is useful for some games. The impetus for this accessory was Namco Museum, which lets you rotate the screen to play arcade games in an aspect ratio similar to their original releases.

This is as close to a copy of the AstroX Switch top plate as I could get. I scanned it in and tried my best to get all the measurements right, etc. The top plate is a curvy beast so I had to eyeball some lines with splines, but it matches up pretty well.

The intention is for this to be used as the basis for top plate attachments (GoPro, etc).

The Fusion 360 file is included, as is the STL.

Source Scan: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0BzdeNQRdjNzDZVVTcjdZTTFYVVk

description.text: I noticed that a lot of people were breaking their Run Cam Micro Swift Camera Lock Ring. I created this as a better alternative to the lock ring. It is designed to be pushed onto the lens almost to the adjustment point. When you screw the lens in it should tighten up right at about the focus point and final torque is the focus its self. It actually seems to also remove any jello caused by the lens. Also works on the foxeer lens. Enjoy. If you like it buy me a beer.

author: kmcclain

description.text: its a sr 72 black bird air plain

This is a fairly easy puzzle to 3D print, however it is a fun & challenging puzzle to solve!

Don't forget to leave me a tip of whatever you can afford- even $1 helps! And once you print the model out share a picture here.

Print these pieces to make 1 Puzzle:
• Quantity (Two) of "piece 1"
• Quantity (Four) of "piece 2"
• Quantity (Four) of "piece 3"
• Quantity (One) "piece 4"
(PRINT WITHOUT SUPPORTS)

How to Assemble:
Sanding surfaces and gluing with Epoxy worked well. Don't sand the inside sliding pieces ("piece 3) or the surface they touch (inside "piece 2"). I will slightly contradict this in the next paragraph.

Post Print Cleanup:
This is an intermediate difficulty print because some low-grade printers will have issues printing the holes cleanly. If you have a bit of a mess inside the holes you can fix this easily- I had a sanding file that fit inside so I used that to clean the holes out. Be careful not to sand the holes too much because that can increase the friction inside the holes and the rods won't be able to slide. If you don't have a sanding file , you might try a drill bit that is just smaller than the hole or some other similar sized object that you can clean the hole by just jamming it in.

Follow me to see what designs I post next.

Thanks.

-Jon

description.text:
This is a rack for use while etching circuit boards.
I had just been laying the boards in the tank but I wanted to be able to etch multiple boards and to use a bubbler to increase the speed I was etching and so this rack was born.
The large slot underneath is for three aquarium stones.
Personally I do not use Ferric Chloride as it is a very nasty chemical that is toxic and difficult to dispose of. I use Ammonium Persulphate instead. Its just as cheap and available and comes in a powder so it has an indefinate shelf life. Disposal is as simple as flushing it down the drain. I have recently been evaporating off the water and it leaves behind pretty blue crystals.

Print on a big printer like a Prusa or other Reprap printer.
Place 3 Aquaculture Aquarium Stones from Walmart underneath in their slots. Length is up to you but this object is designed to so I can print 2 of them and use on 10 inch stones.
Connect air pump
Fill tank with etchant
Place circuit board on edge in slots
Start air flow
As mentioned above I recommend using Ammonium Persulphate as an etchant. It is MUCH safer to use, is a lot less toxic, and is very thin so shouldn't interfere with the stones. Ammonium Persulphate comes as a powder and is mixed with water. Unlike Ferric Chloride it maintains its low viscosity and has the consistency of water. It also will not stain anything.

comments.text: Ferric chloride is nasty, but not that toxic you make it out to be. Flush with enough water and you'll be fine. It will stain your clothes though.
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

comments.text: Ferric is toxic and will attack more than just copper and stains. I don't and won't use it. Ammonium Persulphate is less toxic, just as cheap, just as effective, won't stain and allows you to actually clearly see the circuit board while etching so why not use it instead. I heat my acid but not to boiling. With ammonium persulphate solution a temp of ~100F is as high as you really want to go and it works well. When I was in high school we had a machine that used aquarium pumps to flush a heated solution over the circuit boards. Turn off the system and the board is left high and dry. That system could completely etch a double sided circuit board in under 10 minutes. Due to viscosity, it only worked with ammonium persulphate.
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

Hmmmm I've never printed a helmet as is, but I dont see why it couldnt be done,
You would need to let your slicing software work out what support material amount would be required inside an out.
ABS or PLA. The sizing is currently already round a "small" childs size. If you can afford to trial it, I guess the worst case scenario is you'd possibly waste a roll of plastic, then go for it. Cheers Jace
comments.author: jake10

comments.text: Thanks for the reply.  So when you print a helmet this big, you print that pieces separately and assemble them?  If so, how do you assemble them? Using some type of glue?   Thanks.
comments.author: Jace1969

comments.text:
Hi Jake, not familiar with PLA but I belive you need a two part apoxy glue to bond together.
But for me I use ABS and with a little ABS waste in a container of acertone it becomes a liquid glue and welds ABS beatifully and almost imediately, Less time holding parts. The downfall to ABS is you need an enclosure and to adhere properly use the ABS juice slurry on your print bed to help eliminate warping. Good Luck Cheers Jace

title: 18 whiteboard marker teacher cady
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed a durable way to hold all my 18 colors of whiteboard markers and eraser. I made this holder in TinkerCAD to practice working with the geometry.

V2 is a bit narrower and the internal ridges help keep your markers upright.

I added vertical ridges to strengthen the print. If you have the original file, please disregard and print this beefed up one. This holds 18 expo brand or similar markers.

https://www.youtube.com/edit?o=U&video_id=CGUAwwN0L6Y for an experimental time laps / stop motion animation minifig film.

I had fun putting hexagons through the box to save material. I printed this without supports, so you can use this as a torture / overhang test for your printer.

TAZ 5

Doesn't Matter

0.3 - 0.4 mm

I recommend a brim to hold it down.

The traces are wider and I added a header for an external 5v source in case your programmer doesn't provide it.

I have attached the board and silk screen Bitmaps for the toner transfer process of making boards.
They are 600 DPI and are already flipped the correct way. Print Bottom.bmp onto your paper of choice. I use glossy thin ads from the newspaper. Transfer onto prepared PCB. I use a laminator for this. Etch with your preferred solution. Optional: Transfer Silk.bmp to the top of board to make it look (semi)professional. Populate with sockets, headers, LED and matching resistor, and one jumper wire. The LED will be hanging off the edge if you cut it right down to the line.
Im not sure if this will cause a problem with sending this out to a pro shop or not.

author: Laessen

title: PC USB-C 5.25" Drive Bay Front Panel

description.text:
update made a few adjustments so things fit better now, which should make it accept usb connectors that don't leave much clearance. New version is still much easier to plug in to than the original metal plate.

To breath life in to my old PC, I wanted to add USB-C to the front panel in the DVD drive slot. I found this floppy disk drive usb hub. After using it for a while, I was frustrated with how hard it is to plug things in. The design makes it easy for the edges of USB connectors to get stuck if you don't line them up quite right. So here's a solution!

This drive bay adaptor is sized to precisely fit the PCB linked above, and has 45° chamfered edges leading in to the USB sockets. It's super easy to plug things in to, and prints all in one piece. It's even designed with lighting in mind. If you print the first 1mm in black and the rest in a translucent plastic, you can add an LED and plastic rings around the ports will glow neatly.

title: Spool Holder V2 - Quick Change 2020 Edition

description.text:
This is a remix of "New Prusa i3 MK1 & MK2 Spool Holder V2 - Quick Change" (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1768975) by IsmaelPR1 (https://www.thingiverse.com/IsmaelPR1/about).

I really liked his design, and am printing one for my Prusa MK2S, but I wanted a matching holder for my Tevo Tarantula. I remixed this so the holder can hang on a 2020 extrusion. There's a provision for M4 screws to mount it to the back of the extrusion.

title: Night Stand Coaster (glows in the dark)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I had two goals with this project:

  • I wanted to make it easy to find my glass of water on my night stand in the dark.
  • I wanted to experiment with inlays on a single extruder printer.

So I designed this simple coaster that has inlays of luminous PLA, so it glows in the dark!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25 mm

Notes:

Print the base with any PLA, and print the inserts with luminous PLA, and glue them together.

The metrics in the .stl files are producing a tight fit on my printer, you may need to slightly resize the models before slicing in X-Y direction.

I designed these models in Fusion 360, so I uploaded the .f3d files, in case you want to edit them.

Besides the measurements of the circles, the only "trick" in the models is the 0.4 mm fillet at the bottom of the inlays. I added this to compensate the deformation that is caused by the glass I have on my print bed.

title: Tevo Tarantula Electronics Enclosure .case - RPi Edition

description.text:
I saw this enclosure and had to make it my own! This is a remix of the super cool Tevo Tarantula Electronics Enclosure .case (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2466139) by Aynareth (https://www.thingiverse.com/Aynareth/about)

I saw this in my search to make my Tevo great, and immediately grabbed it. It was only lacking one thing...a provision for my Raspberry Pi 3. I have fixed that now! The Pi installs onto the lid of the enclosure, and I have added a cutout to the case to expose the USB and Ethernet.

If you're not using a Pi, I recommend visiting https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2466139 and getting the original. They have a multitude of fan sizes for their covers. Mine is only for 40mm fans.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

1.5

Infill:

20

Notes:

Print and install!

Please Note:

I haven't fully tested how warm the pi will get being so close to the mosfet. Please take care not to melt your gear!!

The cutout for the USB and ethernet is a tad small. It's actually the exact dimension, but it doesn't allow for shrinkage. You may need to shave the opening.

The logo on the lid is my company logo and it has been removed from the model...sorry.

title: Tevo Tarantula Inverted Z (Single or dual)

description.text:
This is my take on the Tevo Tarantula inverted Z. I've tried sseveral really good setups, but they were just a bit too much. I wanted to streamline it a bit, and I used my Prusa MK2s as a muse. I have provided files for the original Left and Right, Top and Bottom brackets that I currently use. I have also updated the top brackets to shorten the skirt on one side to allow taller travel of the z axis. There is also an updated set of bottom brackets that have a 5mm pad that sits under the vertical extrusion, in case you are incorporating it with a set of existing brackets that lift the printer. This just helps steady it up a little.

You can use one side or the other for single Z, or use both for dual.

This was part of my quest to Prusa-fy my Tevo Tarantula.

Hopefully it all makes sense!

description.text: This landing skid system is desinged for Mini Flame Wheel Style Quadcopter Frame.  It can be hot glued or bolted on the the arm bolts.  In my pictures I hot glued since my bolts where not long enough but it was designed to be bolted on.  I used a 3/16" wood towel for the skids.  The legs have good flex to them and seem pretty strong for this Quadcopter.

Printed with PLA, 25% fill 2 shells. Used wooden dowels for the landing skids and super glued the dowel to the skids. You can bolt on the skid arms or hot glue them on. Got the idea from the Crossfire Quad skids. Drop test loaded Quadcopter.
Hot glued can be dropped from 1-2 feet without having to be re-glued. Bolted was not yet tested due to that I didn't have long enough bolts to bold the skids on.

comments.text: Thanks, printed these today, seem like they will work much better than the other ones that have been posted.  I will upload a pic once I get a dowel glued.

title: Human Ribosome Structure from within Intact Cells

description.text:
Human Ribosome in situ generated from entry EMD-5224 at the Electron Microscopy Data Bank (EMDB) at PDBe (https://www.ebi.ac.uk/pdbe/emdb/). Subtomogram averaging was used to generate a map with 39Å resolution. The publication that references this map is entitled "The three-dimensional organization of polyribosomes in intact human cells" by
Brandt F, Carlson LA, Hartl FU, Baumeister W, Grünewald K. Mol. Cell. 2010. 39(4):560-569.

Printer Brand:

Zortrax

Printer:

Zortrax M200

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.09mm

Infill:

Low

Notes:

A small extra blob of density needs to be removed from the STL before printing.

The model was polished in a sealed small polypropylene tub. Aluminium foil was used to stock the model sticking to the tub. Tissues wetted with a small amount of acetone were placed in the tub (not touching the model) and incubated for 1h at room temperature (21oC). After this time the model was inverted and the process repeated with freshly wetted tissues. Once the additional 1 h incubation was finished the lid of the tub was removed and the model was allowed to dry at room temperature.
The map was downloaded from the EMDB and converted to a surface in Pymol. This was saved as a WRL file. The WRL file was opended in Solidworks and saved as an STL file.

author: ML_SYD

title: 9g Servo Mounting Clips
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Clips that hold servos in place when building with foam board. This removes the need to glue servos into the foam, making it easier to swap servos from one project to another without destroying the previous project, or having to clean off old glue. Perfect for Flite Test style foam board airplane construction. Or any other foam board projects.

This is sized and tested with Tower Pro 9g servos mounted in, R.L. Adams Foam board.

Make sure you add an extra 1/8" to the length of the opening to allow room for the servo and the thickness of both clips. The Tower Pro 9g servo is about 7/8" long, so I typically cut my openings at 1" and they snap right in.

I sometimes use a pick or tiny screwdriver to help pry/wiggle the clips over the servo, and to remove them. Using to much force when installing/removing may damage the surrounding foam board. Practice installing on a scrap piece before installing on a project.

I am proud of this one, the idea just came to me while I was removing and trying not to destroy a plane, and the idea was so simple. Servos are cheap, but who wants to wait for shipping, or waste money even if it is only a few dollars each.

Note: I model knowing the limitations of my 3D printer. Its old and has a few minor quirks. In general its accurate but holes especially tend to print out smaller than they are sized in the model. As such I model holes slightly larger to accommodate this. Test print any part and make sure any attached hardware like wire or skewers fit properly before bulk printing.

A simple expandable mounting for a smartphone.

  • There is a lot of room for remixing on this design (adding more degrees of freedom).
  • Making it more stable.
  • Making it more lightweight.

This was a quick design, the main screw needed some rework post-processing (I had to cut off the knob then glue it back into place after threading it through the g-clamp base.

I have attached the *.STP file here so that everyone has full control of the design if it needs to be remixed.

All the parts are held together with M6x40 bolts and M6 lock screws (M6 washers as well)

You can tighten the bolts until the linkage is sufficiently tight.

I would suggest gluing on a rubber pad on both faces of the G-Clamp (where it interfaces with the table/mounting surface) , also a non-slip pad can be glued onto the smartphone holding surface.

I used some random extension springs on the two ends of the smartphone mounts to always keep tension on the phone.

There is a lot of room for improvement and experimentation on the design.

Have fun!

Printer:

XYZ da vinci jr

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%-50%
NGSS CCSS

All the printed parts (note that the knob has been cut off from the screw) Printing the parts I printed all the parts using 1.75mm PLA. I set the infill for the screw as 50%, all other parts were printed at an infill of 25%. The layer height was set as 0.2mm. And the print speed was set to low. All parts barring the arms were printed with supports. The main screw- I cut off the knob to enable the screw to thread through the G-Clamp body, once threaded through I glued the knob back on. Assembled clamp Assembling the clamp I sanded down all the rough edges and rough sanded out all the holes using a round needle file. Extra attention should be given to filing/sanding the screw threads as the smoother they are, the better the fit to the G-Clamp body. I then spray painted all parts black. Assembly is easy, you don't need to start at any particular point, just assemble as shown in the picture. (M6x40 bolt, 2X M6 lock nuts, 2X M6 washers) per joint.

Making a modular clamp Diverge from the pictures There is no need to keep to the pictures you see here, print extra arms, or extra pivots if you want, it is all modular and will still bolt together. Try to modify some of the parts for added vibration stability.

Materials needed -1.75mm PLA or ABS plastic
-Glue stick
-Needle file set
-Sand paper (180 grit and 80 grit)
-Spray paint (optional)
-M6x40 bolts (5 in total - for the design shown)
-M6 lock nuts (10 in total - for the design shown)
-M6 washers (10 in total - for the design shown)
-Extension springs (2 needed - diameter 5mm, extended length 100mm)
-Super glue (Instant bond glue - compatible with plastic)
2-5 weeks

title: E3D V6 HotEnd (3mm) Mount for BCN3D Sigma R16-17 Machine

description.text:
This is an adapter to mount E3D V6 Hot Ends to the BCN3D Sigma R16 or R17 machine.

This mount will go in place of the standard metal mount. Should be lighter and should mount at the same height as the original hot ends. So no hitting limit switches or anything during bed calibration as what happen with other mounts.

PARTS NOTICE:

Layer Fans:
I used a different layer fan other than the Stock one that comes with the Sigma machine. I ordered: "24V 40mm Blower Fan 4020 40mm x 20mm Turbo Cooling 3D Printer Rep Rap 2pin" from E-Bay

E3D Parts:

  • v6 HotEnd Full Kit - 3.00mm Bowden (24v)

Note: Sigma hot-end fans (not layer fans) are 12V! When you order your hot ends, you need to order the 24v version in order for it to work with your sigma. However the fans will also come for 24v and that will not work!. So right after I placed my order in the E3D website, I sent a notice to the staff kindly asking them to switch the fans in my order to 12v. They where kind enough to swap them for me.

Hope you enjoy the mount! If you have any suggestions, please write to me or leave them in the comments. I will do my best to implement anything that improves this!

THIS IS A TESTED WORKING MOUNT, I HAVE 3 machines running with them for long hours now

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20-25%

Notes:

I used standard ABS For Printing. Worked well without melting or any other kind of issues since the place that the hot-end gets held is not hot enough to melt. Some people reported success even with PLA.

You can print on any printer, it is a very simple part to print with no special care required. Just try to use at least 25% infill so it can be strong enough to not brake during assembly.

I used Fusion 360, and the models that BCN3D posted on github for the original mounts. And a good digital caliper tool. And a couple of iteration prototypes.

I won't mind sharing the original F360 file on demand.

description.text:
Sometimes we need to modify our CNC machine in order to achieve our machining goals as quickly and as efficiently as possible. CNC machines such as plasma, plotter cutters, lasers need mechanism that helps with measuring of material surface.

Good example of such modification is Floating Z axis.

The concept is pretty straight forward: Z axis has its own movable unit which is able to move when tool encounters with material surface.

You will also need:
6mm shaft for linear bearing, length 85mm, 2 pcs

35mm x 9mm x 0.7mm spring, 4 pcs (I found them in "spring assortment box")

More information on our web site:
https://planet-cnc.com/floating-z-axis/

title: Another motorized Marble Machine #3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Another motorized variant of Tulio Laanens fabulous Marble Machine #3. A video is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qM1W1ws6z9Q

This is for an inexpensive pancake style geared synchronous AC motor with 7mm shaft with a flat. These are available in various voltages and RPM ratings. For safety, I suggest you use a low voltage AC wall wart (e.g. 12V AC) and select a motor accordingly. The base has a hole that fits a standard panel mount DC connector, which needs a 10.9mm hole. The motors are available with different gearing which of course will dictate the feed rate. I selected 30 RPM, but you can definitely go slower if you like, and possibly even faster, although I did not try that. The motor must be CW rotation. I bought mine here: http://www.ebay.com/itm/AC5V-6V-9V-12V-24V-110V-220V-TYC-Plastic-Gear-Synchronous-Reduction-Gear-Motor-S/231968344955

If you have already made the track, you do not have to reprint. You can modify it for motorization simply by drilling a 10mm hole in the middle of the bottom plate. I suggest you print a new spiral, however. There are 3 variants with different tolerances for the motor axle press fit. I suggest you start with the middle one.

I have also made a new top without the finger hole, but this is not a necessity.

comments.text: That is actually a good point, now that all wall warts are transformer-less. One option is to find an old transformer wall-wart (you can tell by their weight) that is AC output, or easily can be repurposed for AC. Or you could buy a transformer, but then you would need to make a case for it. Or you can do as I did, just using mains voltage. The motors are available in 110V and 220V.

author: rkarr

print_settings.Notes:: Happy to take any criticism as this is my first attempt at a self designed project.

description.text:
This is my first upload to Thingiverse. It was an experiment to see if the design would work for storing the cards and was made on Tinkercad.

This was created as a test for the storage of the standard set of Sushi Go! cards. Had a few issues with the printer but I will put that down to user error.

Printer:

Da Vinci 1.0 AiO

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Best to print the face part with the face on the bed to save on filament for support material. Tested with an older model and the face insert is fairly loose. Have increased the sides without testing so it may need to be modified slightly after print.

The same is required with the body, this can be printed rounded side down. Supports will be printed to the central band.

Happy to take any criticism as this is my first attempt at a self designed project.

For afterwards...

I have had to post process quite a bit, this was due to my own personal issues with the printer and support material was being really stubborn. My original print was slightly too small for the insert so I have modified the STL files to hopefully rectify this. There is no locking mechanism for the face to the body so this may cause issues with the box opening whenever it feels like it.

Just starting out.

I have used Tinkercad, a very good online resource to get started with. I have designed a few basic items on there for personal use but this is my first upload.

title: DIY GoPro BT Remote Panorama stand

description.text:
This is a Bluetooth remote control Gopro Hero3+ stand for shooting Panorama photo. An arduino is used as the controller and it accepts simple serial commands listed below. You can use the linear combination of those command to program your required motion through free apps. Enjoy!

Demo: https://youtu.be/zLUe8WmqM-c

Part list:
MG90 servo 180deg x1 ; up/down
MG90 servo 360deg x1 ; 360 rotation ver or hacked it
M4x25 x1
M4 nut x1 (with lock)
M4 washer x1
M6 nut x1 ; for mounting on standard tripod
4mm metal ball x 18
Bearing M4 1305 x1

Hardware:
Arduino Pro-mini + BT module + Android app

Arduino Connection:
D10-> Base Servo
D11-> Up/dn Servo
RX -> Bluetooth TX
TX -> Bluetooth RX
5V -> Bluetooth VCC ; better to use 3.3v
GND -> Bluetooth GND

Arduino Sketch:
Sample sketch was provided.

Basic serial command list:
[8] = Up 1 step
[2] = Down 1 step
[4] = Left 1 step
[6] = Right 1 step
[5] = Home
[0] = Wait/stop for 1s
[?] = Help

Apps:
By using free Bluetooth apps like "Bluetooth Serial controller", each buttons on your phone can be programmed to different text string. For example, you can program the button with output string “40404040” which will drive the Panorama stand to turn left for a step, then wait for 1s and the repeat this for 4 times. Have fun!!

remixed_from.author: jprikkel
remixed_from.title: MakerBot Replicator 2 Filament Tube Holder and Centered Feeder

title: Remix: MakerBot Replicator 2 Filament Tube Holder and Centered Feeder Double Barrel!

description.text:
This is a double-barrel version of jprikkel's filament tube holder. The filament tubes on my Rep. 2 just kept popping out, so I searched and found this gem. It just needed a couple tweaks! ;-)
I shorted the down-tab, as it hung just a little lower than the original tube holder's top, and I wanted this snug against the cable block. I also bridged the two parts together and notched the down-tabs to allow for the zip-tie holding on the cable bundle. Included is a photo of the tag attached to a coil of plastic tubing I bought at the local Lowe's hardware for a Vox box I was making for my brother-in-law. It is a perfect match for the original, so they are probably from the same source.

I think I sliced it with 2 shells, 15% infill and 0.3mm layer height in Makerware, built it on my Replicator 2.  Pop out the popout tabs and snap it into place.  I had to cut and re-zip the zip-tie holding the cable bundle in place, as the zip head was in the way; it's centered now.  Good luck with your build!

comments.text: Nice update. Love it!

description.text: Building a battle drone for Game of Drones (https://www.facebook.com/GameOfDronesCA) This is the base/top plate I designed in Sketchup.

print_settings.Notes:: the carriage is bolted together with 3mmx30mm bolts

description.text:
been using this for a week or so now and its proven to be far more reliable than using standard LM8uu bearings commonly seen in x-carriages.

In terms of vibe reduction its un-matched, even using the more expensive LM8uu there remains a degree of vibration as the mini ball bearings within the bearing casing travels along the axis rods but this carriage literally has zero vibration I can detect (the noise reduction is also a further added benefit).

though this design has features to make it compatible with my Poltur and PolturXL extruder mount design its still totally compatible with standard i3 x-axis's setup.

Ive also included the STL for my extruder mount with this thingie as the two together work excellently and allows the user to quickly,easily and cleanly remove the extruder mount with minimum fuss without need to upset the x & z axis calibration.

In the future after further testing and proven reliability (fingers crossed) I intend to replace the z & y axis with similar designs and ultimately dispose of the need to use bearings entirely

Printer:

PolTur XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

25%

Notes:

my initial design used ABS but I found that ABS had more trouble acquiring the correct tolerances for the bearing replacement teeth and took more post-print sanding to get right.

I made a second prototype out of PLA and the rigidity and tolerances were almost exactly what was required with only the lightest of post-print edge sanding to make everything fit as snug as possible.

I used some high grit level sandpaper wrapped round a 8mm axis rod to very lightly sand the bearing teeth faces to get rid of any minor filament imperfections (to ensure the teeth glided along the axis rods smoothly) before fitting.

the carriage is bolted together with 3mmx30mm bolts

title: "around too it" - I finally got dual extrusion!

description.text:
If you look thru my things, you will see several other versions of "round tuit's". My dad loves these, he is a puny guy!

In honor of my new Ultimaker 3, the first dual extrusion file I tried was of course a round tuit!

I designed the original in Onshape, but now prefer Autodesk Fusion 360. So I exported the original as an IGES file, then extruded from the base of the letters then deleted the original solid, leaving the letters I needed to bring into Cura 2.7 for slicing.

Merging the 2 files went off without a hitch! I did notice a difference of the bottom letter size (if the letters are printed first vs. second) due to "squish" of the plastic/first layer.

description.text:
Replaced the battery on my moto360 gen 1 and damaged the back cover. This part is no longer available for purchase so took the one from Goryaschenko which was the whole back unit and changed it to be just the back plate\cover.

It isn't water proof after you replace the backcover.

You will Need;

  1. Clear plastic A4 sheet (used by transparency foil) - this is for the window for heart rate monitor
  2. Glue (I used model glue - Tamiya Cement - no expert in glue...)
  3. 2mm 3M double sided tape

Instructions;

  1. Print out the part
  2. Cut small circle in A4 transparent sheet to fit in the window area (see picture)
  3. Glue in place
  4. Apply double sided tape on back of watch
  5. Put it together:)

Enjoy

comments.text:
Just wondering why have the heart rate opening and an opening covered with plastic, and not just have holes instead. I'm just asking as I would think the holes my give some cooling while charging. I am going to print and try to drill small holes in the plastic. Please don't think I'm second guessing I'm just wondering and think this is a great print. I found this after I ordered 2 backs from China. But I am going to print after I open and replace my battery. (I have 2 watches with same issue of needing a battery).
Again great print, thanks.
comments.author: bbouch

comments.text:
Put the plastic sheet and glued in place so that it is still somewhat water\sweat proof...
You could leave tiny holes instead and just close up the back, but this seemed better.

A mini skateboard, 140 mm (some 5.5") long. It is printed in three runs. I use "brim" around the smaller parts. Needs some super glue to complete ;-) Wheels should turn. I am new to 3D printing, will appreciate comments to learn new things.
SketchUp

There are a couple of frame support postings already on Thingiverse and I modelled this on the work of eychu. His posting uses 10mm screw rods and doesn't include SCAD files so I had to start from scratch to make some compatible with a standard i3 frame.

The rear 8mm threaded rods on the I3 should be replaced with 370mm versions and two additional 370mm 8mm threaded rods are needed for the diagonals. In addition 16 off 8mm nuts and washers are required.

The angle of the rods are 20 degrees to match the 100mm distance between the frame and the rear y-corners as specified in the Prusa instructions

The frame in the pictures is CNC cut from 6mm Di-bond - a really good material to work with and with the support is completely rigid.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/87JBx5fxjx9

title: Catalina 22 Cockpit-Drain Grating
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a debris grating that fits into the cockpit drains of early Catalina 22 sailboats. (Second-generation and likely first-generation; I believe 3rd- and 4th-gen boats switched to transom drains.) Two are required.

The idea is to keep leaves and other junk from clogging the drain lines while the boat is moored or parked on a trailer, since clearing the hoses and through-hull is a monumental pain in the ass. I would think carefully about leaving them in place while underway as they obviously reduce the flow rate through the already too-small drains.

description.text:
The idea with Basic Trailer Project is that you can combine standard parts to make your
own trailer design. It is built with screws and nuts so you can change, upgrade, repair
or take it apart and build something else.

Twist and turn the objects so that the print fits you and your printer.

I have already built a flatbead trailer and I will make some improvements on this one,
which is going to be a 20' container link trailer (picture borrowed from Fliegl).
I will divide this project in separate parts, mainly because I don't think I can manage it any other way. That's why it's going to take a couple of months or so to complete..
I use it with my Tamiya Volvo FH12, but it will probably fit all trucks at 1/14 scale.

Everything is NOT 3D-printed, and it will cost some money to buy these things,
but I think it will be worth it. I've bought parts from different places and I will
add measurements and ev.links.

This trailer requires some tools and knowledge, it is not a toy that 4-year old can build.
Some drilling and sanding is necessary.

Links to Youtube where you can see the trailer I've already made.
https://youtu.be/RwmbYtY6y9Q
https://youtu.be/LUuadFUUwXA
https://youtu.be/wwyBKh6TZkA

Frame Parts required:
U-profile alu 20x10x1,5mm
U-profile alu 10x8x1,3mm

M3 assortment , screws in different length, washers and nuts (try to get some square
nuts to, quite handy)

title: PS 3 Eye Laptop Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I designed this to securely mount my PS3 Eye camera to a thin laptop screen. The camera needs to be disassembled to replace the original mount with this. For those that has removed the IR-filter and/or the optic this is just a matter of 5 screws.

For added friction I recommend to add a thin strip of hot glue on the inside of the front tab and maybe even on the clamp.

Materials needed:
1 pcs M2.5 nut
2 pcs M4 knurl nut (standard nut sorks as well)
1 pcs M4x35mm hex screw

Use an soldering iron to melt the nuts into the plastic.

NOTE: There's two variants, one for thinner screens (like laptops) and an other for thicker screens (like desktop monotors).

title: CR10 MULTI Camera Mount Z axis for Pi Cam Logitech c270 c310 c920 9000 CR-10

description.text:
This is a Camera mount that goes on the X-axis Stepper cover, the advantage is that it goes up and down with the Z-axis and thus keeps the printhead and top layer in sight at all times in addition you avoid the vibrations caused from the jerky motions of the printbed.

There are currently 4 Bases
A - Super Extra Distance ;) (EZABL or other sensor support) (screws on printers x axis cover with default screws)
B - Standard
C - Extra Distance (EZABL or other sensor support)
D - Extra Distance with screw support (EZABL or other sensor support) (screws with printers X-axis Endstop with default screws)

Cameras Currently Supported

  • Universal Mount for all cameras, should be used only with mount A, can be mounted horizonaly, vertically, upside-down center rear forward... camera can be beld on either by screws, velcro, double sided tape, or cable ties through the slits above the screw holes)
  • Logitech C270 Direct without extension A or B or C or D (Can use pin from default camera mount or a 3x22 screw with a nut)
    Manual Focus <!--(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fJYqHhkq42M)-->
  • Logitech C310 Direct without extension A or B or C or D (Can use pin from default camera mount or a 3x22 screw with a nut)
    Manual Focus same as C270 above
  • Logitech 9000 (Thanks to Norbert Zalog for testing :) )
  • Logitech C920 with the extension and Mount A (installation video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3KyxeIcd1Uc&t=7s)
  • PICam (Seperated into 2 peices front and back)
    -Waveshre PI Cam with IR or similar 2 peices front and back
    -PS3 Eye CAM 2 peices bottom and top (Needs Testing if you try please comment if it worked for you)
  • Microsoft VX-xxxx (Credit goes to zoombee download from this link "https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2723134"
  • Microsoft Lifecam Studio (Needs Testing if you try please comment if it worked for you)
  • Microsoft Lifecam 3000 and similar

  • GoPro

  • if you have a model not listed and would like to see it please Comment

Here's a timelapse from the mount https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1xcqQ8varPI

Open to suggestions and Input please Comment

You can visit my site www.fission3d.com for 3D Guides and other STL files

If you like my work and would like to support
Please Donate :)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30 %

title: DIY FPV Splitscreen for Racing Events

description.text:
Last year, at the FPV race in Bexbach, I had an idea to build a fpv splitscreen for the next events to watch the races from the perspectives of all pilots.

Unfortunately, I have not finished my project to the Friedewalde FPV Festival. In Nördlingen I now had my prototype for the first time and was amazed how well the device worked. Since the first photos on Facebook I had many inquiries, so I decided to write an article about it, of course. Have fun while reading and building it yourself.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qjpqND_KArc

EN: https://blog.seidel-philipp.de/diy-fpv-splitscreen-for-racing-events/
GER: https://blog.seidel-philipp.de/fpv-splitscreen-fuer-racing-events/

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Notes:

PETG

author: ps915

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53807

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=53807

Using the following options:

row_four = 4
nubs = 0
row_three = В
number_per_day = 3
row_six = 6
row_five = 5
Length_For_Each_Compartment = 20
row_one = У
Height_For_Entire_Model = 15
Width_For_Each_Compartment = 35
row_two = Д
number_days = 7

A Dual Y rail setup with bed stiffening for the Tevo Tarantula.

Replaces the stock drive belt mounts on the Y axis with mounts that also hold the Y rails.

Also on the perspex bed frame, I have added support stiffeners that double as the Y rails bearing mounts.

This stops the perspex warping under the pressure of the bed levelling springs which caused me no end of headaches when trying to level the thing...

This now gives me a solid strong level bed...

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2-0.3

Infill:

Slic3r 20% Ideamaker 40%

Notes:

The resolution is up to you, but be aware the Y rail mounts will probably require boring with a 8mm drill bit...

The bed stiffeners were printed in ABS but PETG would do fine.
The Y mounts where printed in cheap PLA... Again up to you what you want to print in really...

You might also need to drill out the mounting holes.

Also when designing this, the extrusion profile I was designing off is ever so slightly different to the actual one on my printer. So I had to file the extrusion slot guides down a little to make it fit... You may also need to gently mallet the thing in the first time... (it was that snug)

You will have to drill the perspex bed frame for the mounting holes, perspex is brittle so be careful. I recommend using some kind of pillar drill for that with a sharp fast bit.

Also ive not really built much tolerance into this design. in my case the Y rails arnt quite as free moving as I would like. And while not totally binding are a little more stiff than I would like.

I might be able to fix this in the future, but for now it works...

Also optional, you can carry on using the stock V Groove wheel and rail setup with this if you like. Though i have not tested without, this might be part of the cause of stiffness due to the natural shortcomings of 3D printing accuracy.... Experiment.

Things you need to buy...

2X 500mm 8mm Diameter rails.
Get chromed hardened steel, and when you get it make sure its not bent in any way...

I got a 100mm rail and used a grinder with a cutting bit to cut it in half.

Not sure if your rail is hardened steel? Easy to check... Try cutting it with a hacksaw. If the teeth glide over its hardened... if the teeth cut in, its soft and unless for a printer....

4x SC8UU mounts with bearings....
Various nuts and bolts.... M4 M3 M2... Just get loads...
but for a slightly more accurate bill...

The SC8UU require 16X M4 15mm length.

The bed stiffeners require
32 M2 bolts and nuts... Though you can get away with a few less...

The rail mounts use the T nuts and bolts from the stock mounts...

comments.text: After an absolute bed nightmare trying to get the the linear wheel bearings system to get the bed level I decided to go down this route, I found your files very helpful indeed and totally did away with the wheels and went with just the two rails (I used an 8mm solid brass polished rod) Now my printer is so much more predictable and reliable thanks for sharing these files and happy new year to you, Happy making :)
comments.author: ady1306

author: skydiver01

description.text:
A thing to put on the ends of I-beams, so things you lean or hang on them won’t get scratched by the metal edges.

The neighbour kids very neatly put their bikes on I-beams supports of the court yard’s barrier, out of the way for everybody else. I noticed (too late) that this scratches up the bikes’ paintwork, and came up with this solution.

This is, as somewhat customary for me, a little parametric. Change the lengths in the FreeCAD file’s “sizes” spreadsheet, turn into an mesh and export for a differently sized version.
There is also some design history available at my github repo.

Support Z modifié par Nicolas Boulay
La pièce a été agrandi de 45mm, les deux pièces font donc 90mm en plus sur l'axe X.

Pourquoi 90mm ? Car les tiges de bases de l'axe x font 270 et que j'avais des anciennes tiges de 360mm (axe y) (anciennes que j'ai remplacé par des tiges alu igus) donc pour éviter des achats supplémentaire, voila pourquoi 90mm

Liste des courses :

  • Une nouvelle courroie (1m)
  • 4 tiges de 360mm

Pour toutes questions, vous pouvez soit me contacter sur le groupe Dagomaniack sur Facebook (Melvyn Perard) où dans la section commentaire sur Thingiverse

Printer:

Dagoma DiscoEasy200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

This is a coupling I designed for the 28BYJ-48 stepper motor to connect it to an M4 screw or threaded rod.

It comes ready with support to enable it to be printed in horizontal direction, so the resulting part will be strong in rotation axis direction. The dimensions should work well with PLA 0.2mm layer, it prints well without any additional support.

Post printing a little sanding might be appropriate. Screw and rotor should fit in with no force, depending on the application a drop of glue might be needed to keep them in place. The M4 is meant to be fixed by double nut.

description.text: Based off Cellstruder v1, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:109040, except it has the ability to retract the syringe. Therefore, it has an enclosed design with a lead nut for retraction on the lead screw. It also has a switched up lm8uu holder to add a better grip over the linear bearing. Last, included is a syringe holder for a standard printed x-carrage. Enjoy!

• 100mm Long 8mm Wide Lead Screw
  • Corresponding Lead Nut that have 4mm openings
  • 4mm Wide Screws 10mm Long
  • Nema 17 Motor
  • LM8UU
  • 125mm Smooth Rod
  • 26mm 5x8mm Motor Coupler Shaft
    • As written in Cellstruder v1
  • Luer Syringe Tips 20 Guage, 1.5''
  • Male, Female Adaptors 1/16''
  • 1/16'' 25ft Silicon Tubbing
    • Note: Since it is enclosed you have to remove the plunger from the barrel, insert the barrel then add the plunger for the 20mL. For smaller syringes, they easily slip through. Note: Use Sli3er to slice these as other slicers might read the Stls with their inside boundary lines, such as Cura. For questions contact, [email protected]

Support plateau modifié par Baptiste Gonon-mathieu
PontH modifé par Moi

  • 4 écrou M3
  • 4 écrou M3 nylstop
  • 4 aimant 10X3 (https://fr.aliexpress.com/item/Free-shipping-wholesale-30pcs-disc-10x3mm-N50-rare-earth-permanent-industrial-strong-neodymium-magnet-NdFeB-magnets/2019230280.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.OGDPwJ)
  • 4 aimant 10x3 percés M3 : (https://fr.aliexpress.com/item/10pcs-10-x-3mm-Hole-3mm-N50-Strong-Ring-Magnet-DCountersunk-Rare-Earth-Neodymium-Magnets-Permanent/32794495954.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.OGDPwJ)
  • Ressort Diam. 18 (Leroy)
  • Superglue

Aucun support sauf pour "PontH" ou il faut mettre le gros cercle pour les ressort vers le haut

Printer:

DiscoEasy200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Il faut mettre un écrou nylstop dans la pièce PonH, puis un aimant troué à l'opposé de l'écrou. Ensuite une vis M3x35 et en sers bien (pas trop quand même car l'aimant risque de se cassé)

On place le ressort à l'endroit prévu et on exerce une pression pour faire sortir un bout de vis du coté du support plateau et on mets la mollette avec un écrou M3 puis on sert le tout.

Enfin, avec de la superglue, il faut coller la pièce "Aimant plateau" sur le plateau. Prenez des mesures pour que ce soit droit.

title: 3D Printed Bearing (without balls)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
EDIT:

  • Added a tiny MR126 bearing - 26th October 2017
  • Added a 605 bearing - 11th January 2018

  • Added 606, 623 & 695 - 16th January 2018

  • If your part is stuck together after printing it, squeeze the bearing with some pliers :-) (see video below)

  • lubricate it with Silicone-Spray, PTFE-Spray or other lubricants to your liking, which doesn't eat the plastic.

If anyone needs other sized bearings, let me know, the inventor file is easily adjustable (for me) hehe

https://youtu.be/8A6JIjDRq3E

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 or finer

Infill:

3 shells + 25% infill

Notes:

Outer diameter is exactly the measurement it should be. Inner is a big bigger.
If your printer is printing it out a bit smaller (like mine did) scale X&Y a bit up/or down. whichever works for you.

The "3D Printing Professor" was talking about 3D printed bearings.
Better said, he used one for is fidget spinners.

Since I couldn't find anywhere that file, I designed one myself.

So the "Remixed From" is more like a "Inspired by" ;-)

title: Spool holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Spool holder (screwed shaft type)

shaft-holder

Basic spool shaft holder for 20 mm aluminium frame.

shaft-holder-2

Modified version for my 3D printer. Height from a aluminium frame surface to center of the shaft is larger than basic one.

Spool-shaft-dd-ll

Screwed shaft to hang a spool.

  • dd : Diameter of shaft at center in mm. Diameter on the end of the shaft is +5 mm of this value. Spool hole must be larger than this value.
  • ll : Length of shaft in mm. Spool width must be smaller than this value.
